questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except:
questions.solution:
Boundaries of the Calot’s triangle is not formed by the gall bladder.

Calot's triangle is formed by 3C's:

  • Medially – Common hepatic duct
  • Inferiorly – Cystic duct
  • Superior – Cystic artery 

 

Clinical Note: Proper exposure of Calot's triangle and careful identification of the anatomic structures are keys to avoiding common bile duct injuries. This is the most common site of injury in laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Related Pearl: Calot's triangle and hepatobiliary triangle

Boundaries Calot's Triangle Hepatobiliary Triangle

Superiorly

 Superior border of the Cystic artery Inferior surface of the Liver

Medially

 Common Hepatic Duct

Inferiorly

 Cystic duct

Importance: 

Contents of Calot’s triangle:

  • The cystic artery—artery supplying the gallbladder
  • Lymph node of Lund—sentinel lymph node for the gallbladder

The above ECG shows ventricular tachycardia.

The features in the above ECG suggesting the diagnosis are as follows:

  • Wide QRS complex with abnormal morphology (marked with red arrows)
  • Absence of the P waves
  • Rate >100/min- in the given ECG, it is ~180 beats/min (1500/no. of small boxes between two R waves)

 

Ventricular fibrillation would have no discreet QRS complexes. The given ECG shows ventricular fibrillation:

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal dominant?
questions.solution:
Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder.

It is caused by a mutation of the fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR-3) gene.

The primary defect is abnormal chondrocyte proliferation at the growth plate that causes development of short and thick bones.

Clinical features:

  • Short limbs
  • Normal trunk
  • Large head
  • Saddle nose
  • Exaggerated lumbar lordosis
  • Severe spinal deformity may lead to cord compression

Related Pearl: Inheritance pattern of important diseases

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below ?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis from the above image is pterygium. 

Pterygium:

It is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea.

It is a degenerative condition of the sub-conjunctival tissue.

It is a connective tissue disorder and is never inflammatory. 

It is made up of three parts:

  • a "cap" (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge),
  • a head,
  • a body.

Occurs due to exposure to radiation: UV-B.

The most common site is nasal.

Clinical features:

  • Astigmatism with the rule, usually
  • Stocker's line deposition of iron on the advancing edge.
  • Fuchs islets are small, discrete, whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells, often present at the advancing edge.

Differential diagnosis is pseudo pterygium. 

Pterygium Pseudo-pterygium
Degenerative process Inflammatory process
Occurs in elderly  Can occur at any age
Situated at the palpebral aperture Can occur at any site
Either progressive, regressive, or stationary Always stationary
Probe cannot be passed underneath Probe can be passed under the neck

Treatment: Excision

To prevent recurrence

Mitomycin C or 5 fluorouracil

  • Auto-grafting: Conjunctival limbal autograft (CLAG) from the superior limbal conjunctiva is the best method.
  • Bare sclera technique has high recurrence rate of 30 to 80%.
  • PERFECT surgery has zero rate of recurrence.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image :
questions.solution:
The condition in the given image is acanthosis nigricans.

It is a skin condition is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.

The causal mechanism is due to the secretion of epidermal growth factor in the region involved. It can be benign or malignancy-associated.

Benign acanthosis nigricans is often associated with obesity or insulin resistance, it is common and usually mild.

Malignancy associated acanthosis nigricans is much less common. It is usually associated with gastric carcinoma, lung carcinoma, and uterine carcinoma.

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

  • Drugs such as Nicotinic acid used to treat hyperlipidemia 
  • Sudden onset of multiple seborrhoeic keratosis

questions.text: Which of the following actions of GH is mediated by IGF–1?
questions.solution:
Antilipolysis is mediated by IGF-1.

The actions of growth hormone mediated via IGF-1 (somatomedin-C) are the indirect effects of growth hormone and include:

  • Antilipolytic activity
  • Insulin-like activity
  • Protein synthesis
  • Epiphyseal growth

The direct effects of GH include:

  • Sodium retention
  • Decreased insulin sensitivity
  • Lipolysis
  • Protien synthesis
  • Epiphyseal growth 

Related Pearl: Direct and Indirect (mediated via IGF-1) effects of Growth Hormone

Indirect effects of growth hormone are mediated via IGF-I (Shown in blue in the image). 

Direct effects of GH are shown in orange in the image.

questions.text: A 5-year old child from a refugee camp presents with generalized oedema, tachycardia, and palpitations. Signs of heart failure are present and a chest X-ray reveals massive cardiomegaly. Lab markers reveal low RBC Trans-ketolase activity. Which of the following vitamin deficiency is likely to be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette in a child is suggestive of Wet Beri-beri. The vitamin deficiency associated with this condition is thiamine (Vitamin B1).

Wet beriberi (cardiac) is associated with Tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, edema. It is commonly seen in the refugee camps where people consume polished rice-based monotonous diets. Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

Dry beri-beri is associated with neurological deficits such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability.

Thiamine deficiency can also be named based on the pattern of dietary deficiency seen. These would include, oriental beri-beri (diet predominantly including polished rice) and occidental Beri-beri (a diet rich in refined flours and food fads). The latter form is commonly seen in alcoholics.

Complications include lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy in adults.

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamine)

Serum methyl malonate level

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

Deficiency State

Burning foot syndrome (historically called as "Nutritional melalgia")

Dermatitis, enteritis, alopecia, ataxia

Microcytic anemia, convulsions, depression

Biotin (B7)

Relatively unknown

Folic acid (B9)

Cobalamin (B12)

Pernicious anemia, dementia, spinal cord degeneration, homocysteinemia

Ascorbic acid (C)

Scurvy

Ecchymosis, bleeding gums, poor wound healing, fatigue, joint effusion, Scorbutic rosary

Epidural hematoma:

Noncontrasted axial computed tomography scan showing a lenticular area of increased density in left parietal region.

  • Typically occur in the groove of the middle meningeal artery associated with temporal bone fractures that have resulted in a tear of middle meningeal artery.
  • They tend to not to cross suture lines of the skull.

Subdural hematoma:

A non contrasted computed tomography scan of acute subdural hematoma shows a cresentric area of increased density in the right posterior parietal region between brain and the skull. An area of intraparenchymal haemorrhage also seen. In addition, mass effect causes a midline shift to left.

  • They can cross suture lines but they do not cross the tentorium or falx.
  • Can be acute or chronic

Subarachnoid haemorrhage:

A non contrasted axial computed tomography scan shows the blood as areas of increased density near the base of the brain shows blood in Texaco star pattern formed blood radiating from suprasellar cistern into the sylvian fissures and anterior interhemispheric fissure.

  • Most often accompanied by severe sudden onset headache.
  • Can really be visualised in acute stage, when blood is radiographically dense (whiter) than the CSF.

Intracereberal haemorrhage:

Non contrast computed tomography shows a large area of fresh blood appearing white in the region of right thalamus. Blood is denser than CSF so settles dependently.

This settling is not seen with subarachnoid or interparenchymal blood.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: A 60 year old woman presents with low backache and on a lumbar x-ray the following is seen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts ballooning of disc spaces leading to biconcave shape of vertebral body known as ‘Cod fish appearance’, classically seen in osteoporosis. 

It is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T score less than -2.5. It is the gold standard to assess bone mineral density.

Other radiological features of osteoporosis:

  • Loss of vertical height of vertebra due to collapse
  • Ground glass appearance of bones especially in the bones like pelvis
  • Loss of cortical bone (picture frame vertebrae) and trabecular bone (ghost vertebrae)
  • Loss of trabeculae in proximal femur area.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score of -2.5 or lower, that is, a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below :
questions.solution:
The image depicts laryngeal papilloma.

Laryngeal papillomatosis

  • The viral origin associated with HPV infection 6 and 11.
  • More common in the anterior part of glottis especially anterior commissure. Most common site is vocal fold.
  • More common in children< 5 years.
  • Transmission: exact mode not known, but recognized association exists between maternal genital warts and recurrent laryngeal papillomatosis.
  • Treatment: Primary modality of treatment is surgery. Endoscopic surgical removal is the preferred treatment. Most commonly used modality is a Co2 laser. Recurrence is common and multiple procedures often required.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopic agglutination test is used for diagnosis of Leptospirosis.

History of fever with liver(icterus) and kidney(hematuria) involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis (Weil's disease).

Serotype-specific tests:  

  1. Microscopic agglutination test 
  2. Macroscopic agglutination test 

Regarding other options :

  • WIDAL test is used to screen for typhoid fever
  • Weil Felix reaction is used to diagnose rickettsial fevers  
  • Paul Bunnell test is the investigation of choice for infectious mononucleosis.

 Leptospirosis is an underreported disease and it is estimated to cause 48,600 deaths worldwide annually.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lower abdominal mass and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and adnexa is free. MRI shows the presence of a myometrial cyst. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiparous women > 40yrs, presenting with abdominal mass with free adnexa and myometrial cysts on MRI, all point towards a diagnosis of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis (Endometritis interna):

Adenomyosis is ingrowth of endometrium ( stromal and glandular components ) directly into the myometrium.

Etiology: Vigorous curettage, repeated childbirth or excess of estrogen

Clinical features:

  • Multiparous females >40 years
  • Most common symptom: Menorrhagia > Dysmenorrhea
  • Pelvic discomfort, backache, dyspareunia
  • Per-Vaginal: Symmetrical enlargement of the uterus ( corresponding to <12-14 weeks of pregnancy )
  • Bimanual examination: Halbans sign: Tender, softened uterus

Diagnosis:

  • It is mainly clinical
  • Diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage

Management of adenomyosis 

  • Total Hysterectomy ( Treatment of choice )
  • Localized excision/ Levonorgestrel containing IUCD is tried in younger women.

questions.text: An intern placed an intercostal drainage tube in a patient. Which of the following steps is incorrect?

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.solution:
Intercostal tube is placed along the upper border of lower rib, in order to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle.

Inserting and managing a chest drain:

An intercostal tube connected to an underwater seal is central to the management of chest disease.

The safest site for insertion of a drain is in the triangle (Triangle of safety) that lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • Above the level of the nipple;
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will ideally find the fifth space. The technique includes the following.

  • Meticulous attention to sterility throughout.
  • Adequate local anaesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; these should only be the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract, so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and the
  • Drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung. A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base. The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. The retaining stitch should be secure but should not obliterate the drain.
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is vital for pneumothorax management but should be omitted if the drain is for empyema (provided there is adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  • Connect the drain to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • After completion, check that the drain has achieved its objective by taking a chest radiograph.

questions.text: Which of the following is an oral factor Xa inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Rivaroxaban is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor. They represent a new class of oral anticoagulant drugs that do not require monitoring.

This group of drugs inhibit factor Xa in the final common pathway of clotting [conversion of Prothrombin (Factor II) to thrombin (Factor IIa)]. They are given as fixed doses and have a rapid onset of action.

Oral direct factor Xa inhibitors are indicated in:

  • Prevention of embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation (without valvular heart disease)
  • Venous thromboembolic disease (VTE)
  • Postoperative thromboprophylaxis in patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

 

 

Classification of Anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist

Warfarin
 
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)    Oral DTI

Dabigatran
Parenteral DTI 

Monovalent DTI- Argatroban
  Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin
 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors  Unfractionated heparin
Low molecular weight heparins  

Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin
Fondaparinux
 
4) Direct Oral Factor Xa Inhibitors  Rivaroxaban, Apixaban, Edoxaban, Betrixaban

questions.text: Which lymphoma is strongly associated with overexpression of BCL2?
questions.solution:
Follicular lymphoma is associated with overexpression of BCL2.

Follicular lymphoma

  • Arises from germinal center B cells
  • Usually, presents in the middle age.
  • (14;18) translocation
  • BCL-2 is the inhibitor of apoptosis and causes promotion of the follicular lymphoma cell.

Clinical features

  • It presents as painless generalized lymphadenopathy with less commonly the involvement of CNS, GIT, or testes.
  • Median survival is for 7-9 years
  • In almost 50% of patients, this cancer gets transformed to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

Lymph node biopsy

  • Closely packed follicles
  • Centrocytes (small cell with the cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm) and centroblasts (large cell with open nuclear chromatin and multiple nucleoli).

Bone marrow

  • Para-trabecular lymphoid aggregates
